query: Help me set up the Sports Coach Engine. I'm on a Mac and not very technical.
expected_behavior: Detects macOS platform using uname (returns Darwin)
Checks for WSL (should not match on macOS)
Checks Python version and finds it missing or too old (< 3.11)
Explains what Homebrew is in non-technical terms (package manager)
Guides Homebrew installation with clear instructions
Handles potential Xcode Command Line Tools requirement gracefully
Installs Python 3.11+ via Homebrew with explanation of each step
Verifies Python installation (python3 --version shows ≥3.11.0, exit 0)
Detects Poetry availability using poetry --version
Uses Poetry for package installation (poetry install)
Explains what Poetry does (dependency management, virtual environment)
Verifies sce command is available (command -v sce returns exit 0, sce --help returns exit 0)
Runs sce init to create configuration structure
Validates environment (all checks pass: Python ≥3.11, sce works, config exists)
Provides clear success message listing what was accomplished
Seamlessly transitions to first-session workflow for Strava authentication
Maintains conversational, non-technical tone throughout
Never switches context to external documentation (HTML guides, etc.)
Explains technical concepts using analogies (virtual environment = sandbox)
Provides visual confirmations (prompt prefix indicators, output patterns)

quality_criteria.conversational_tone: All explanations use non-technical language appropriate for beginners
quality_criteria.adaptive_workflow: Skips steps that are already complete (e.g., if Python 3.11 already installed)
quality_criteria.error_handling: Gracefully recovers from common errors (Xcode CLT missing, PATH issues)
quality_criteria.educational_moments: Explains WHY each step is needed, not just WHAT to run
quality_criteria.context_preservation: Handoff to first-session maintains conversation flow without explicit skill invocation

anti_patterns_to_avoid: Directing user to external documentation (breaking conversation flow)
Running commands without explaining what they do
Proceeding to next phase before validating current phase success
Assuming user understands concepts like PATH, virtual environments, package managers
